Award.AwardTitle: Phylogeny and diversification in the uniquely diverse beetle family Curculionidae (true weevils)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The lack of a reliable family tree for the extraordinarily diverse beetle family Curculionidae (true weevils) has impeded taxonomic, systematic and applied research on weevils. This project will reconstruct the family tree of Curculionidae and establish a timeframe for weevil diversification by analyzing genomic and morphological (anatomical) data. The genomic data gathered will consist of DNA sequences from 1,000 species representing all major groups of weevils, obtained via an approach called anchored phylogenomics. This will be one of the first applications of this new method for gathering phylogenomic data in insects.

Curculionidae contains >51,000 named species and is one of the largest families of animals on Earth. Because of their intimate and often highly specialized interactions with plants and fungi, Curculionidae are among the most significant pests of agriculture and forestry worldwide, and some of the most abundant insects on Earth. This project will clarify the interrelationships of all major groups of weevils for the first time. The resulting family trees will be used to test long-standing hypotheses about weevil relationships and evolution, and will contribute to resolving the taxonomic problems that both pervade the internal higher classification of weevils and impede research on economically and ecologically important weevil species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Because of their intimate and often highly specialized interactions with plants and fungi, weevils (beetles in the superfamily Curculionoidea) are among the most significant pests of agriculture and forestry worldwide. They are also some of the most abundant insects on Earth, occurring in most terrestrial habitats, and even some aquatic ones. The lack of a reliable family tree for the extraordinarily diverse weevil family Curculionidae (true weevils; more than 51,000 named species) has long impeded taxonomic, systematic and applied research involving weevils.

This project sought to reconstruct the family tree of weevils, with a particular focus on Curculionidae, and to establish a timeframe for weevil evolution. This was accomplished by analyzing molecular data from hundreds of nuclear genes and morphological data from adult, larval, and fossil weevils. The molecular data gathered consisted of DNA sequences from more than 1,200 species representing all major groups of weevils and their nearest living relatives. These data were obtained using a new method called anchored hybrid enrichment, followed by next-generation DNA sequencing. By analyzing the resulting data, we succeeded in clarifying the interrelationships of all major groups of weevils. Moreover, we generated a uniquely comprehensive family tree for the weevil family Curculionidae, opening the door to lower-level studies of this uniquely species-rich radiation of plant-feeding beetles. The resulting family trees and other data we generated are helping to resolve problems with weevil classification. These problems have long impeded research on economically and ecologically significant groups of weevils. Finally, we succeeded in reconstructing the genomic basis and evolution of plant-feeding in weevils and their relatives. An additional notable outcome from this research is the recognition of a new family of living weevils (Cimberididae).

Our reconstructed timetree for weevils is consistent with a Mesozoic radiation of gymnosperm-associated weevils to form most living weevil families and diversification of Curculionidae alongside flowering plants—first monocots, then other groups—beginning in the Cretaceous. Additionally, we documented the diversification of plant-feeding weevils following horizontal transfers of microbial genes, enabling weevils to digest woody plant tissues efficiently. Our findings thus clarify the weevil family tree and reveal new insights into the evolution of specialized plant-feeding and why there are so many species of weevils. In addition to these research-related outcomes, we successfully developed and implemented public outreach and education programs (about insects and biodiversity) involving the Pink Palace Museum, the University of Memphis, and elementary and middle schools in the Memphis area.
